title.rendered: Eight Ways to Lose Weight Naturally with Ayurveda

content.rendered:
Ayurveda, a 5000-year-old science of self-healing, or integrative lifestyle approach to whole health has a different perspective to weight loss than the Western view. One of the key differences of east to west is the way the body is understood. The allopathic approach( western) sees the body as the sum total of parts. If a part needs fixing it gets replaced. Weight loss is narrowed down to calorie deprivation, overexercising, or fad diets that we know don’t last. The eastern approach, Ayurveda and TCM ( traditional Chinese medicine), sees the body as a superhighway of channels, meridians or nadis, that connect body, mind, emotions, and spirit. Almost like the internet of our own being. Energy healing such as Marma and acupuncture seek to unblock energy pathways that may be affecting the thyroid, the digestive area, elimination and so on while addressing the emotional causes of overeating. Some are stress, anxiety, depression, grief loss, hormonal imbalance, past and present trauma. Without addressing the root cause whether it’s overweight or underweight one cannot truly heal, but only temporarily reach a goal that is not maintained. So what can the wisdom of Ayurveda impart about losing weight naturally?

Here are eight ways to lose weight naturally with Ayurveda:

  1. Learn your Ayurvedic energy type. Ayurveda provides a unique map for the psychological and physiological makeup of an individual. It is not a one size fits all approach. Each of the energy types is balanced with various tastes such as sweet, sour, salty, bitter, pungent and astringent. For example- A Kapha type person who is mainly having the sweet taste may be prone to gaining weight but while introducing bitter, pungent and astringent tastes are more likely to reduce weight. To find your energy type take the quiz on my services page www.gedaliahealingarts.com/services. Provide the answers based on how you have been your whole life. To learn more after the quiz schedule your Ayurvedic Lifestyle Consult with Gedalia.
  2. Sipping hot water throughout the day can break up fat cells and induce weight loss. It’s such an easy practice and one you might start enjoying year round. You might want to add a bit of Neem honey ( which is anti-inflammatory ) to taste just before you sip the hot water. If you are Kapha type please omit.
  3. Aim to eat seasonal foods. By eating with the seasons you are harmonizing yourself with nature- both within and without. By creating that kind of balance you will naturally lose weight. For example: Don’t eat watermelon in winter. Select the fruits and vegetables that are local and in season in your region. Having a CSA delivered to your home is one of the best ways to accomplish this.

Your grandmother was right: In the summer, you should eat lighter fare, like salads, and leave the heartier stews and soups for winter. Doing so could help us lead healthier lives – and possibly also lose a few pounds, a top expert says.

“We should be eating according to the seasons. We’ve known this since Paleolithic times, but over the past 60 years, we lost sight of it,” John Douillard tells Newsmax Health.

“The season of summer is the best season to transition to a healthier diet,” says Douillard, author of the book, “The Three Season Diet.”https://www.newsmax.com/Health/Health-News/Seasonal-Eating-Diet-Weight/2017/08/23/id/809345/

  1. Eat at regular times and don’t skip meals. The regular habit of eating the same time creates a rhythm in your biology that it can depend on. Skipping meals can lower blood sugar and increase calorie consumption at the next meal. In the following article from Health Site, it says:https://www.thehealthsite.com/fitness/7-reasons-you-should-not-skip-meals-ever/

#1. Changes in your blood sugar levels

Sugar — obtained from the breakdown of carbohydrates — acts as our body’s fuel, which is required for its normal functioning. So if you skip a meal, your blood sugar levels drop which in turn affects the functioning of your organs.

#2. Affects your mood and concentration

Do you know that glucose (obtained through food) is the main source of energy for your brain? Hence, if you skip a meal, your brain will receive less glucose (energy). As a result, it experiences a shortage and you will feel tired, sluggish, moody and irritable. This also interferes with your ability to concentrate, thereby leading to a decrease in your performance at work or school.

#3. Alters your metabolism

According to Dr Neha, ‘Skipping meals on a regular basis shifts your system into starvation mode. This is an effort by the body to store energy. However, not eating your breakfast or dinner, decreases your overall metabolism and slows down the weight loss process.

5. Find ways to reduce stress. Ten to fifteen minutes of meditation daily is a good start. Everyone can meditate. Just as sleep is natural to our bodies, meditation flows freely when you allow the mind to unwind in its true nature- peace. Discover various meditation styles in my book guide ” Enough Drugs I am A Woman and Can Heal Naturally- a practical guide to feeling your best. You can be sure to find something there that will resonate with your style.https://www.amazon.com/Enough-Drugs-Woman-Heal-Naturally/dp/0692811613

6. Avoid snacking. By eating three meals and not snacking in between you give your body ample time to digest the previous meal. Aim to have your last meal by 6pm.

7. Develop a regular daily exercise approach. Walking, swimming, biking, bouncing on a rebounder all practical ways to increase your metabolism.

8. Receive Marma therapy, Ayurveda’s energy healing. By unblocking energy pathways, you are increasing energy flow and circulation throughout your entire being- body, mind, and spirit. Stress, anxiety, depression, grief, and loss melt away leaving you feeling lighter, more grounded, focused and able to meet daily life with increased vitality. Marma is anti-aging and increases blood flow to the skin making you look younger and more refreshed. By removing stuck energy you are optimizing your weight loss goals.

My website has details of where I offer Marma and for client testimonials.http://www.gedaliahealinggarts.com

Check out my upcoming interview on energy healing in the April Natural Awakenings magazine in Atlanta.

with warm regards,

Gedalia

excerpt.rendered: Ayurveda, a 5000-year-old science of self-healing, or integrative lifestyle approach to whole health has a different perspective to weight loss than the Western view. One of the key differences of east to west is the way the body is understood. The allopathic approach( western) sees the body as the sum total of parts. If a […]

content.rendered:
Dear friends,

As the year 2018 wraps up you may be reflecting on what was, and what will be. Pressured with goals for the New Year including weight loss, perhaps a change of career, passing an important test exam, an overdue divorce, a move, a creative endeavor, or the care taking of an elderly parent,your mind becomes overwhelmed. Holiday shopping is in full bloom, politics is on fire , (along with the real fires in California), your social media time has increased, your sleep reduced, and the parties have just begun. Whew, we are all busy!

How do you find happiness amidst all this? Shouldn’t this season be joyous? festive? happy? How do I feel happy with so much to do?

The three major blocks to happiness:

1. Living in the past or in the future

You got the first one- living in the past or in the future. Accepting “what is” brings us into the now. Eckhart Tolle in his book “Power of Now” describes this well. The book is intended to be a guide for day-to-day living and stresses the importance of living in the present moment and avoiding thoughts of the past or future. Self acceptance and acceptance of ” what is” brings our attention to the essence of our being ( whether we judge it or not) that then leads to inner calm and freedom. Seeing something in it’s true light means acceptance and that includes us- our bodies as they are, etc. etc. etc… (you may fill in the blanks.)

So for NOW I invite you to take a deep breath and Pause. You may ask yourself, what can I accept today that can reduce my suffering and anxiety? Acknowledge it and feel compassion as if your best friend just told you this story. Accept it into your being. Offer it to nature, or a body of water or to fire.

2. Comparison

I’ve already clued you on the next one – comparison. Ah, you look at social media and someone else looks more glamorous, has a gorgeous partner, or appears to be living the perfect life. Social media can get one thinking this way. Reflecting inwardly on your innate gifts is probably not something we do enough of. Thanking ourselves, loving ourselves, even though…… we have limitations is the antidote to comparison. Just for today, take five minutes in silence and thank yourself for things you like about yourself. See how that feels. Are you smiling? Do you have good things to say about yourself? Are you feeling shy? Jot them down in a notebook or journal to look at when you’ve forgotten to love yourself.

3. Postponement

When I retire, I will… When I lose weight, I will… When I get the right partner… when I pay off my debt, I will… when I get a face lift, I will… The third enemy, postponement. What did you postpone this year? One of the reasons we may postpone something could be connected to self doubt. “Someone else knows how to speak in public better than I can or on Facebook or Instagram” – ” I look too old to speak on the computer camera”… ” I started so many diets and failed”… The antidote- accountability and short term commitments. For example, I will walk three days this week. I will post one new Facebook live this week. Whatever you’ve been postponing  aim to break it down in smaller steps.

As the next few weeks bring a close to the year 2018, here are three things that could increase  your happiness:

  •  Spending a few minutes or even seconds each day focusing on your breath, being aware of your body, and entering a state of mental calmness has been linked to a wide variety of physical and emotional benefits.
  • Exercise. 30 minutes of exercise, cardio, or yoga releases a surge of endorphins through your body, thus improving your mood and decreasing your stress levels.
  • Spend time outside. Nature is a proven stress relief. Taking a stroll through a nature-rich environment can quickly lower blood pressure and reduce stress. 

Allow yourself to experience the happiness you deserve!!…. NOW!

with warm wishes and love to all of you,

Gedalia

Photo by David Marcu on Unsplash

title.rendered: One GREAT Holiday Self Care Practice

content.rendered:
Hi everyone,

Great to be back for another week of sharing with you all. I would imagine that everyone is or has been experiencing some digestive murmurs from the big turkey dinner festivity and coming up is Hannukah and Christmas. No doubt we might be eating more food than usual or indulging in foods we regularly don’t eat. For me, it’s been that wonderful hot chocolate with whipped cream I save for this time of year and some fried potato pancakes, a staple of  the Hannukah tradition coming up. Thanksgiving stays under control for the most part for me. Although I did try a shot of caramel shnops at the end which was way good.

But nevertheless, it’s cold, we are probably eating more mac and cheese than last season, or extra fats to keep us warm. All good. This is natural in winter.  Since you know I like to come from a nurturing place, not denial, I am sharing with you One GREAT Holiday Self Care Practice- Ayurveda’s Digestive Tea. 

As you can see from the picture I already got a head start- please join me in this daily ritual and let’s think of each other as we sip our tea! I’ve been making a pot a day and drinking it throughout the day. The recipe is easy:

2 parts fennel seeds (2 Tbsp) 

Benefits:

  • Helps Regulate Blood Pressure
  • Reduce Water Retention
  • Fennel Tea for Constipation, Indigestion, IBS & Bloating
  • Fennel Seeds Reduce Asthma Symptoms
  • Helps Purify Blood
  • Improves Eyesight

1 part cumin seeds  ( 1 Tbsp)

Benefits:

  • Promotes Digestion. The most common traditional use of cumin is for indigestion.
  • Is a Rich Source of Iron.
  • Contains Beneficial Plant Compounds.
  • May Help With Diabetes.
  • May Improve Blood Cholesterol.
  • May Promote Weight Loss and Fat Reduction.
  • May Prevent Food-Borne Illnesses.

1 part coriander seeds ( 1 Tbsp)

 Benefits:

Coriander seeds have numerous key vitamins like folic acid, vitamin A and beta-carotene, and most importantly, vitamin C. According to Madhavi Rathod of Vedic Healing, coriander leaves and seeds contain nearly 30% of the everyday suggested measure of vitamin C, which helps in curing cold and flu.

10 cups water

Bring all ingredients to boil then simmer for 15 minutes- strain. I purchased the ingredients at the Dekalb Market in Decatur. I like to keep it in a carafe and drink all day. My husband likes it too.

I hope you find this daily ritual a kind and loving way of supporting your body to digest all the good foods you will be partaking in. And who knows you might want to share some with your friends and family! I sure hope you do.

 

with fierce love,

Gedalia

Dear friends,

There are many types of honey nature has provided and they are quite beneficial for your health but Ayurveda focuses on one in particular called neem honey”.

Neem honey is revered in Ayurveda for it’s medicinal properties and healing value.

These are three essential benefits:

  1. Neem honey is anti- inflammatory. Especially around the holidays/ and entering the winter season, neem honey is a good preventative self care item for your daily routine both to enhance your immune system, improve digestion and reduce stress. It can be used to treat throat infections and even limit allergies.
  2. In Ayurveda it used for hypertension or high blood pressure to help regulate the blood. Neem is also used to treat diabetes.
  3. In Ayurveda it is used for skin problems both taken internally and directly used on the skin.

Here are a few suggested ways to incorporate neem honey into your day.

  1. Take one tsp first thing in morning then follow with hot water.
  2. It can also be taken with tea.
  3. Neem honey can be applied to the face as a mask to improve fine lines and wrinkles.
  4. It can be eaten right out of the jar.

It is best to purchase neem honey raw and unfiltered ( non GMO as well) with companies like ” heavenly organics” found at Whole Foods.

Thank you for participating in my weekly blog.

My in home visits are going well and would love to see you soon.

Wishing you  a love filled holiday with those around you.

 

 

warmly,

Gedalia

Dear friends,

In an article written by John Immel– Joyful Belly, (a great resource for Ayurvedic recipes)- “Develop your Five Senses”  it states, https://www.joyfulbelly.com/Ayurveda/article/Develop-Your-Five-Senses/822

“Five Sense Medicine

Ayurveda doesn’t require equipment or tests. The only equipment required to practice Ayurveda is the five senses. The mind is the 6th sense in Ayurveda. It ‘senses’ the sense organs, and interprets their experiences. Ayurveda places great importance on improving the acumen and strength of the five senses. What if your taste was stronger, your eyes keener, your ears more sensitive? You would have a higher perception of reality. Your sense organs are truly your only means of contact with the outside world. Your sense organs are the best tools you have to keep your body healthy, including selecting the right foods, wearing seasonally appropriate clothing, and even interacting with your community. Here are some simple ways you can strengthen your senses:

Sense Organ How to Strengthen
Tongue Fast, incorporate bitter taste in the diet
Nose Exhale, breathe fresh air, oil nasal passages
Eyes Add alteratives, pitta pacifying herbs, and amalaki to your routine
Ears Be in a quiet space, clear out wax
Touch Stay clean, add massage and dry brushing to your routine
Mind Meditate, practice deep breathing, rest

”

Dr. Deepak Chopra shares that  according to Ayurveda, sensory impressions are considered crucial to health. Just as the food we eat creates our bodily tissues, our sensory impressions determine the quality of our thoughts and emotions. If we aspire greater physical and emotional well-being, we can use sounds, feelings, sights, tastes, and smells to balance and heal our selves. 

It is for this reason that I created the ” inner home , outer home visit”.  It includes tips on balancing the five senses for your inner and outer home- your body/mind and the space in which you live – from essential oils to colors, gemstones, direction of sleep and more.

This unique in home visit balances body and mind during the first hour with Marma Therapy and for the second hour I will assist you in creating balance and harmony in the home or space you are living in- creating a sacred space perhaps? where is the best place for meditation in my home? What colors should I use in my living space?or bedroom? How do I meditate? what yoga postures can help bring me into balance? How can i breathe more fully? Which tastes will bring balance to my body and mind?

No traffic, no stress, no mess.

For more information visit http:/gedaliahealingarts.com/services  Tuesdya’s at Dr. Bindiya with Revive Atlanta MD Decatur  call 678-357-3443 for appts.

Visit my colorful art for a visual lift at https://www.etsy.com/shop/GedaliaHealingArts?ref=search_shop_redirect

I look forward to seeing you soon.

 

with fierce love,

Gedalia

Dear friends,

Essential oils can quickly enter the bloodstream through the skin and with aromatherapy- inhalation. Essential oils affect the ‘limbic’ part of the brain which connects to emotions and hormones. They are truly nature’s gifts. Simply taking a moment to “pause” can shift your awareness to being present and to the breath. Those moments of well being are the ingredients to self care and compassion. I find these shifts in awareness bring a sense of peace and inner calm. How about you?

Essential Oils for emotional support:

Anger

Jasmine, Ylang Ylang

Anxiety

Lavender, orange, geranium

Disappointment

Cypress, orange

Fear

Sandalwood

Grief and Sadness

Rose

Shock

Lavender

Stress

Vetiver, Ylang Ylang, Rosemary, Lavender, Clary sage, Geranium

Mental Clarity and focus

Frankincense-rosemary

Mental energy

Peppermint

Mental stress and fatigue

Eucalyptus

 

Essential oils are best  used when mixed with a carrier oil such as sesame, fractionated coconut oil,  or jojoba.

Two to three drops per oil mixed with a carrier works well behind the neck, ears, or chest. You may also mix oil into a massage oil for your body- up to fifteen drops per 16 oz.  A diffuser with a cool mist works well in the home or office. The company “Now” makes cool mist diffusers.

Holistic practices such as aromatherapy do not replace talking with a friend or therapist.

Therapists I recommend locally:

Sandra Goulding- Emory area- faculty professor- 404-431-5129

Meg Ash- Near Jimmy Carter Blvd- integrates meditation- 404-373-5954

Laura Silverman- https://sweetgrasscounselingga.com/

 To order  Gedalia’s Fall Roll  Oil  go to https://www.etsy.com/shop/GedaliaHealingArts?ref=search_shop_redirect 

The fall roll on can reduce anxiety and promote grounding with oils such as vanilla, jasmine, holy basil and vetiver. Safe for children over 6 years of age.

You can also find my  original art on Etsy as well as the roll on. Ten percent of proceeds will go to Pittsburg.

 

with fierce love,

Gedalia

title.rendered: Five Tips for A Healthy Immune System

content.rendered:
Dear friends,

With the cool weather upon us, I thought I would reshare an article I wrote that was published in the Atl Jewish Times- Five Tips to a Healthy Immune System. Whether you opt for the flu shot or not these five tips are simple self-care practices that you can easily incorporate into your daily life.

http://atlantajewishtimes.timesofisrael.com/5-tips-for-a-healthy-immune-system/

Each season I create an essential oil roll on. For those who know me, my love for essential oils is eternal! I’ve used them both personally and professionally for over 30 years and am still amazed at their miraculous ability to support the mind, body, and emotions. Our sense of smell activates the “limbic” part of the brain which regulates hormones and emotions. I enjoy keeping my diffuser in the kitchen while I cook to inhale the benefits. A cool mist diffuser is preferred over heat to maintain the integrity of the oils. This is an example  https://www.amazon.com/VicTsing-Humidifier-Ultrasonic-Essential-Diffuser/dp/B07GQP3YWR/ref=zg_bs_16250381_4?_encoding=UTF8&refRID=EW60JM43K047MX7QH77S

 The goal of Ayurveda is to create balance and harmony to prevent disease.

Each season of the year  I hand make an essential oil roll-on. In Ayurvedic wisdom, each season holds certain qualities that affect our bodies and mind.  In the Fall we need warmth, grounding, and protection from the dryness and wind. These qualities can affect the body and mind with restless sleep, anxiety, and fatigue. This roll on is made with ingredients such as vanilla, jasmine, holy basil and vetiver in a fractionated blend to decrease anxiety, fatigue and depression. Here are just a few benefits of jasmine oil alone:

Here are some of the most well-researched and loved benefits of jasmine oil today:
  • Dealing with stress.
  • Reducing anxiety.
  • Fighting depression.
  • Increasing alertness.
  • Helping to fight low energy or chronic fatigue syndrome.
  • Reducing menopausal symptoms and working as a natural remedy for PMS and cramps.
  • Helping with sleep.

My Fall essential oil roll-on is now available to order. I am offering Free shipping in the USA. The cost of this oil is $25( includes shipping). Please email me with your requests. gedaliagenin@gmail.com or reply to this newsletter. To read more about how to use and apply oils for various symptoms check out my book ” Enough Drugs! I am a Woman and Can heal naturally- a practical guide to feeling your best”. https://www.amazon.com/Enough-Drugs-Woman-Heal-Naturally/dp/0692811613/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1512947734&sr=8-2&keywords=enough+drugs

View this post on Instagram

“ Let it roll “ -A unique seasonal blend of therapeutic grade essential oils to support grounding and anxiety. When do I apply? Apply before meetings, before heading home in traffic, before meditation , before speaking with your partner or boss and before bed. Apply on your children over 6 years. Where do I apply? Behind ears, on wrists , throat and behind the neck. By taking moments of well being you are building your ability to stay present. Ingredients : Vanilla , jasmine and two more surprises in fractionated coconut oil. Free shipping in USA. Contact me via my website please to order. #essential oils #fall #anxiety #roll #grounding #breath #moments

A post shared by Gedalia Healing Arts PhD (@gedaliahealingarts) on Oct 24, 2018 at 2:01pm PDT

I would also like to share a documentary of my Ayurvedci teacher that has just been released on Amazon- “The Doctor from India”. Vasant Lad was the first doctor to bring Ayurveda to the West. He resides in Albuquerque New Mexico half of the year, where I learned that art of Marma. It is a beautiful story of courage and wisdom about Ayurveda and Dr. Lad’s commitment to this beautiful healing art and science. I highly recommend viewing it.

 

with fierce love,

Gedalia

title.rendered: Essential Tips for the Change of Season

content.rendered:
Dear friends,

Just as you change your clothes every season, so too we need to change our eating patterns each season according to Ayurvedic wisdom.

Seasons have properties or qualities that define nature. As the leaves change color and fall from the trees there is dryness, wind and cool qualities of the earth. These qualities stimulate “vata” both in the environment and within our bodies and mind. 

A homeopathic principle also true in Ayurveda is that ” like increases like” and “opposite qualities heal”. With that said the opposite of dryness in terms of diet is

warm, cooked and oily. This may be difficult if you’re used to having cold smoothies from the summer but it is actually a good time to make a shift.

Nature is giving us warm, sweet nurturing foods such as butternut squash, pumpkin, apples, pears supporting our immune system for winter. If you follow nature you follow Ayurveda. How could you go wrong with that?

You may want to replace your morning smoothie with cooked apples, dates and ghee, and steel cut oats for example. Instead of salad for lunch, you might have a lentil vegetable soup, butternut squash soup, kitchari or wild salmon cooked with vegetables. If your not a cook and want to pick up kitchari you can find Ayurvedic meals in Buckhead at http://samafoodforbalance.com/

The windy quality can often stir a bout of constipation or dry skin. Dry foods such as pea protein, chips, leftovers, microwaved, popcorn, crackers increase the dry quality in our bodies which again is not the goal for this season.

To counteract use plenty of ghee ( hold the coconut oil as it’s cooling), olive oil, and oil the skin with sesame oil daily. This ancient practice of abhyanga is both anti-aging, immune supporting and hydrating for the skin. You can use sesame oil for this practice. For more info visit https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/lifestyle/self-oil-massage/

Once you get into the habit of oiling your skin daily I guarantee you will love the results. It’s grounding, nurturing and gets a big check on the “self-care”‘list.

Be sure to stay well hydrated and if you find your emotions have gotten stirred up spend time breathing, meditating and noting what no longer serves you. Minimize the negative effects of the news and replace it with something fun like dancing, writing a poem, baking or quilting. Aim to let it go or at best witness the emotions with compassion and self-love. It’s hardest to love our limitations but don’t you love everything about your children? Well if you don’t you at least give them acceptance and compassion.

Be extra good to yourself this season and don’t forget to include a “Marma” session for your self-care. It’s anti-aging, grounding, enhances the flow of energy in your body/mind, clears negative energy, balances emotions and hormones, plus…. here is what the Chopra Center writes about it  https://chopra.com/search?keys=marma

For more testimonials about Marma go to http://www.blog.gedaliahealingarts.com/testimonials/

I’ll be in Decatur a few Tuesdays a month for appts.  Also offering in home visits for “new clients” ( not previously form other offices).Call 678-357-3443 or email me.. I look forward to connecting with you.

 

with fierce love,

Gedalia

Dear friends,

 

Before you get tired of eating sweet potatoes, how about trying a delicious orange alternative that will even satisfy a sweet tooth?

Butternut squash, a favorite fall vegetable is chock full of benefits. To name a few, butternut squash is packed with Vit A ( nourishing to the skin), potassium and fiber. A cup of cubed butternut squash also provides 582 mg of potassium, more than the amount available in a banana! Studies have indicated that people who consume more carotenoids, including, beta-carotene are less likely to develop colon cancer. 

Here’s a cool fact-Butternut squash is actually grown in the summer but harvested in the fall to eat as a “winter squash”. 

Here’s how to make Roasted Butternut Squash:

Preheat oven to 400 degrees.

Peel one large butternut squash ( this is good for the hubbies to do)

Cut off ends- then cut in half then quarters then cubes. Place on roasting rack with a Silpat or just on the rack.

In a separate bowl mix three tablespoons melted ghee with one – two tablespoons brown sugar ( I had light brown at home)

Brush the squash with this mixture then add a good amount of pepper to the squash.

Roast for about 45-50 minutes turning once halfway with a spatula. The outside will caramelize into a beautiful brown color.

Hope you enjoy it! Just wanted to offer a “sweet” note this week with all the outer chaos. I find when I turn to nature I feel nurtured and strengthened by its everchanging colors and rhythms.

with fierce love,

Gedalia

Dear friends,

The topic of “truth” has been playing out in our outer world.  I am certain each of us has a response. Ayurveda teaches that what takes place in the macrocosm goes on in the microcosm. While contemplating “truth” these words came up for me. I thought I’d share.

Truth begins with the words you tell yourself.

” I am worthy”

” I am of value”

“I have gifts to share”

( we can each add our own)

 

If you feel stuck in negative emotions you may want to sing, dance, move, create art, take a yoga class, do tai chi, meditate or receive energy healing. Because in this place of feeling “stuck” it is easy to identify yourself with those emotions.

The fall season can easily stir up emotions. Ayurveda calls this season ” vata”. Its qualities are dry, light, cold, and windy.  Try to be gentle with yourself during this time. Notice patterns of thinking and feeling that no longer serve you instead of judging them. Let them fall to the ground of nature so that you may prepare for transformation. May your true colors shine forth!

My recommendation is ” move with the energy”.

with fierce love,

Gedalia

Locations:

Two new locations on the horizon for my services. Decatur and Suwanee. Sandy Spring in January. Will send details soon and feel free to email me. I am also offering home visits. Can’t wait to share.
